titleStmt.title: Burglars From Syria Harran

monogr.title: A Digital Dictionary of Shawi Arabic

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.
Private URIs using the dict prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a entry in the SHAWI glossary.

spanGrp.span: Once, there were two men traveling along the road, may God prolong your life, Teacher Stephan. They were two thieves heading from Turkey to Syria, originally from Harran. These thieves of ours reached a village with the intent of robbing it.

That is, they were raiding. In the past, it was called "raiding." The earlier generations referred to those who stole as "raiders." The Bedouins in ancient times would raid—yes, they would raid—meaning they would go, and when they stole something, it was said that they had raided. They were thieves.

They arrived at the village, and there was a celebration—a big celebration. They were beating drums, and there were elders and a **"zarāda"** (a term likely referring to an object or ritual item) with a fire. They had lit a fire and placed the **"zarāda"** inside it.

The elders entered the fire and placed the **"zarāda"** inside, performing their special rituals. Here, when the elders perform rituals, they strike themselves with a **"šāčriyye"** (a type of whip or instrument used in such ceremonies). They enter the fire and strike themselves with the **"šāčriyye"** as part of the ritual.

We, too, the people of Harran, our group traveled from Turkey and sat down to watch the celebration. A man nearby started conversing with them and chatting. He recognized them, realizing they were strangers—it was clear they were not from Syrian lands.

"Where are you from?" he asked them. They replied, "By God, we are from Turkey. We came as guests, as you can see, as you know." Of course, they wouldn't admit they were thieves—they had to call themselves something else.
The Syrian sitting next to them asked, "Do you also have such rituals? Do you hold similar ceremonies?" One of them, God forgive him—excuse my words, teacher—had a tendency to lie a little.
He said, "Sir, what’s this? We also do the same! We slaughter, skin, cut, beat ourselves, and hang ourselves. We fear nothing at all."

They asked, "You do these rituals in honor of whom?" They replied, "We also have an ancestor, a Sheikh named Ḥayāt al-Ḥarrāni." The man beside him nudged him sharply with his elbow, saying, "You dog, why are you lying like this?"

The man said, "Where did you get this from? Where did you learn to perform the rituals of the sheikhs? You thief, son of a thief!" He continued, "Come on then! Stand up and do what we do, perform the rituals like us!"

The Syrian said to the Turk, "Come on, stand up and do as we do!" The Turk replied, "Give me a kettle. Do you have a kettle? Give me a kettle so I can go and perform my ablution, I'm not in a state of purity. I need to wash and come back to do it, so I can do it like you."
He took the kettle, intending to distance himself from them in order to escape. Isn't he lying? He wants to run away, so his lie won’t be revealed.

When he distanced himself a little from the celebration, suddenly his grandfather, Sheikh Ḥayāt al-Ḥarrāni, appeared to him. He asked, "Where are you going, my son?" The man replied, "By God, this and that..." The grandfather then said, "Tell me the truth, my son!"

"You were there talking and mentioning me, and I became alarmed, so I came to you. I am your grandfather, Sheikh Ḥayāt al-Ḥarrāni. Go, go and perform your ablution, my son, go! Go ahead, don't worry! I am behind you."

When the thief saw his grandfather, he regained his strength. He performed his ablution and went to the fire. When he returned to the fire and was about to enter it, his companion sitting there said, "You son of a dog, now you're going to burn, now you're going to be hung in the fire."

He went into the "zrāda" and wrapped the "zrāda" around his neck, then entered the fire, but nothing happened to him. He said, "Oh, you! Oh, son of a thief, where did you get this from? Where did you get it from?" The thief replied, "Oh, shut up, shut up, don't speak!"

He said, "I was trying to escape, and then my grandfather appeared on the road. The elder Sheikh Ḥayāt al-Ḥarrāni, and he said to me, 'You mentioned me, don't be afraid! Enter! Perform the rituals, don't be afraid!' And I entered the fire, and the Syrian was watching."
He said, "Yes, by God, my brother, that's true. This means that you also have rituals like ours." May God bless you.
